seat: England (Technology & Construction Court, High Court of Justice)
institution: Court litigation under FIDIC EPC/Turnkey contract (stay application)
works: Design, supply, installation, testing and commissioning of 1.5 MW solar energy plant on Council-owned building

core_issues.desc: Whether referral to a DAB was mandatory before litigation
Meaning of 'no DAB in place' and whether this allowed direct litigation
Whether DAB/adjudication process unenforceable for uncertainty (the 'gap' issue)
Whether court should stay proceedings and compel use of DAB procedure

factual_triggers: 7 Jul 2011: Contract signed, EMS to deliver solar energy plant
31 Jul 2011: Deadline for 55kW output to secure higher feed-in tariff; alleged failure triggered £1.3m 'Price Reduction'
2013–2014: Council refused EMS payment application; pre-action protocol letters exchanged
21 Jul 2014: EMS issued notice of intention to refer dispute to DAB
11 Aug 2014: Council issued court claim; 26 Aug 2014 EMS applied to RICS for adjudicator
27 Aug 2014: EMS applied for stay of proceedings
errors_identified: Council argued sub-clause 20.8 allowed opt-out of DAB; court rejected this
Council argued adjudication unenforceable for lack of certainty; court found courts can enforce compliance
Council argued DAB not 'in place' until Dispute Adjudication Agreement signed; court held appointment alone sufficed
outcome: Court granted stay of proceedings. Held DAB referral under FIDIC 20.4 mandatory; clause 20.8 did not allow unilateral opt-out. Dispute must first go through adjudication machinery before litigation.
risk_lessons: FIDIC DAB procedure is a binding precondition to court litigation unless clearly excluded
Clause 20.8 applies narrowly (mainly to standing DAB expiry), not a general opt-out
Courts can enforce DAB/adjudication provisions even if gaps exist (e.g. non-final but binding decisions)
Employers and contractors should ensure DAB appointment processes are completed to avoid jurisdictional disputes
Contract drafters should clarify interaction between DAB expiry, arbitration/litigation, and enforcement

snippets.text: Disputes shall be adjudicated by a DAB in accordance with Sub-Clause 20.4…
If a dispute arises… and there is no DAB in place… Sub-Clause 20.4 and 20.5 shall not apply…
Council’s submissions that sub-clause 20.8 gave it a unilateral right to opt out rejected; adjudication provisions enforceable.
Action must be stayed; parties left to resolve dispute in accordance with contractual machinery.
